summary: Workflow stack traces show compiled JavaScript line numbers instead of TypeScript source line numbers, making debugging difficult. The solution is to generate and use source maps similar to ts-node, which may require building the Workflow Isolate from TypeScript sources instead of compiled JS.
userImpact: Developers cannot easily debug workflow code because stack traces point to compiled JavaScript files instead of original TypeScript sources.
rootCause: Workflow Isolate is built from compiled JS files (./lib) instead of TypeScript sources (./src), losing source map information in the process.
proposedFix: Build the Workflow Isolate from TypeScript sources with proper source map generation, similar to how ts-node handles source maps.
workaround: Use ts-node to get workflow error stack traces with proper line numbers.
resolutionDetails: Implemented source map support for workflow isolate stack traces to show TypeScript source locations instead of compiled JavaScript.
keyQuote: Stack traces should include the source code the way they do in ts-node.
